 POLAND BIELSKO-BIALA WATER AND WASTEWATER PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT PART I. BACKGROUND A. COUNTRY CONTEXT 1.1 Poland's economy continues to perform well. According to preliminary estimates, GDP grew by some 5.5 percent in 1994 (following a 3.8 percent increase in 1993), and is expected to expand by 5 percent this year. The growth was largely driven by strong export performance (24 percent on a BOP basis) and by sustained investment growth (6 percent increase in fixed capital formation). Due to the excellent external performance, the trade deficit was less than US$840 million (an improvement of about US$1.5 billion from 1993), resulting in a current account deficit of about 0.8 percent of GDP in 1994. Consequently, net international reserves of the banking system remained at comfortable levels (about seven months of imports) even after the completion of the debt and debt service reduction operation in late 1994. The budget deficit was kept under control in 1994 at about 2.8 percent of GDP. Inflation has continued to decline slowly; the year-end inflation rate at slightly below 30 percent remained well above the govermment's originally planned target of 24 percent. Unemployment remains high in comparison with other countries of Central Europe; it stood at about 16 percent at the end of 1994. 1.2 Continued economic improvement, with control over inflation and a stable or appreciating currency, will have important consequences for the Municipal Water and Wastewater project. Better economic conditions and improved incomes will help the utility's customers, both households and industrial users, cover the costs of water and wastewater services. B. SECTORAL CONTEXT Existing Situation 1.3 Almost all of the Polish population living in urban areas receives public water and sewerage services. In many places, however, the quality and reliability of service is deficient and facilities are in need of rehabilitation and improvement. Particularly pressing is the need to improve and expand wastewater treatment to clean up Poland's heavily polluted water resources. At present Polish water and wastewater enterprises are generally weak insdtutions with large potential for efficiency gains in management and operation. The Challenge Ahead 1.4 Over the foreseeable future, Poland's water and wastewater enterprises must mobilize large financial resources to: conserve the achievements of the past by rehabilitating and replacing aging water and wastewater infrastructure; expand and improve present service levels and the quality of the water offered to the public;
 - 2 - * upgrade and expand wastewater treatment to clean up the country's water resources; and modernize and improve the efficiency of utility management and operation. 1.5 Mobilizing resources to satisfy all investment needs in the sector will be a difficult task and require a sustained effort for a long time to come. Optimizing resource mobilization and making the best possible use of these resources requires efficient administration and operation of water and wastewater enterprises; improved resource mobilization from all sources, particularly from service beneficiaries; and prudent investment decisions to reserve scarce resources for least cost and high priority investments. 1.6 The Local Self Government Act of March 1990 transferred responsibility for water and wastewater services to municipal (gmina) governments. With the transfer of assets and the freedom to reorganize institutional structures, local governments and their water and wastewater enterprises also have acquired the responsibility for improving and expanding services and, as traditional central government subsidies have been eliminated, raising resources for funding capital investments as well as maintenance and operating costs. The decentralization reforms are providing a unique opportunity to introduce new, more efficient institutional structures and policies on the local level for the provision of water and wastewater services. Many progressive local governments and enterprise managers have launched important initiatives in the right direction-corporatization of water and wastewater enterprises and tariff adjustments towards full cost recovery. Main Areas of Reform Toward Sector Strengthening 1.7 The Bank's water and wastewater sector study proposes a comprehensive program of sector reform. The following reform measures identified in the sector study are considered key to creating strong water and wastewater institutions capable of providing good services at an affordable cost. 1.8 Transfer municipal water and wastewater enterprises into autonomous commercially rum utilities under the regulatory control of local government. Following decentralization of municipal services, a number of local governments such as the Bielsko-Biala municipality, have made significant advances in giving their enterprises the status of limited liability or even joint stock companies; yet many others still withhold the autonomous and commercial status their enterprises need to function effectively. One important task to tackle by enterprise management and local government is to define more clearly the local government-utility relationship in mutually agreed multi-year performance contracts and business plans which formalize the obligations and responsibilities of both parties and provide utilities with the freedom to act like commercial enterprises. One of the major goals of the proposed project is to enhance utility autonomy. 1.9 Improve performance and effciency of municipal water and wastewater enterprises through well focused technical assistance programs. Large changes in the attitude and knowledge of management and staff will be necessary to convert present enterprises into effective utilities. These changes, beginning with redefinition and clarification of the local government-utility relationship and assumption of a utility business attitude requires determined and sustained efforts to strengthen utility management, administration, operation and financial performance through: organizational restructuring; adoption of modern utility management practices and systems; increased focus on maintenance and operational efficiency, including demand management and leak reduction; adoption of corporate planning principles based on multi-year business and investment plans; strengthening financial performance by introducing appropriate tariff levels and structures; and increased consumer orientation and services. To bring about utility reorganization and strengthening, assistance from qualified Western utilities and consulting firms will be essential, at least initially. 'Twinning' arrangements on a commercial, success
 - 3 - dependent basis between Polish and foreign successful utilities might be a good vehicle for transfer of know-how, management and operational systems. These foreign led assistance programs should eventually lead to the development of a strong domestic technical assistance capacity. 1.10 Promote private sector participation (PSP). Growing awareness of the often poor performance of state-run utilities and the realization that public funds alone cannot meet the large investment needs of the sector has led to great interest in involving the private sector in enterprise management and investment financing. Over the last four years, PSP schemes have been pursued vigorously by foreign and local interests. Several preliminary agreements have been concluded, but only one, the joint venture SAUR-local government contract in Gdansk, has come to fruition. All others have not materialized for a number of reasons, including the perception of being too expensive, mistrust on both sides, and sole-source negotiations leading to suspicions of impropriety. After an initial push, the climate for PSP in Poland's water and wastewater sector has cooled, as even the more entrepreneurial utility managers and local governments are reluctant to enter into new deals. Despite this temporary lull, Poland's water and wastewater sector offers favorable conditions for large-scale PSP in the future. Conclusion of more PSP arrangements will depend, however, on an environment of trust developing between private sector operators/investors, local governments and enterprises, with government encouragement. Above all, local governments need to better understand and become more comfortable with the many ways that private sector entry could accelerate improvement of services and bring efficiency gains. Expert independent advice is needed to structure arrangements that are perceived as being fair and advantageous to both parties. Competition in acquiring PSP and transparency of the negotiating process may be a way to counteract negative public opinion. The spread of PSP would be accelerated with the development of a local capacity to offer such services. The govermnent and the international cooperation community can play an important role in encouraging private sector entry by providing advice and encouragement to the sector community and should support specific PSP pilot opportunities. The proposed project, and other "first batch" lending operations in the sector, are expected to serve as demonstration projects that will help foster an enabling environment for future private sector participation. 1.11 Create a suitable facility for financing utility investments. The speed with which Polish water and wastewater utilities can begin to tackle the large investrnents needed depends on their capacity to mobilize financial resources from their own cash flow, environmental grants, private equity and borrowing. In countries with established financial markets, utilities without any initial debt like those in Poland would be able to obtain long-term loans at competitive rates from commercial banks, or be able to tap securities markets by issuing equity or bonds. In the short term, however, Poland's incipient financial markets are not geared to respond to the sector's long term financing needs and other municipal borrowing requirements and direct lending will be required. To overcome the lack of appropriate credit facilities, the government with the support of the Bank and other bilateral cooperation institudons is working on the creation of a Municipal Credit Program'. The purpose of the MCP will be to help utilides and local governments access long-term finance and establish their credit record until the domestic financial sector is capable of providing credit for municipal infrastructure. However, it will take several years for the program to become fully operational and able to meet the needs of large cides. 1.12 Introduce appropriate cost recovery and pricing policies. Full recovery of costs, including operation, maintenance, depreciadon, finance charges, and opportunity cost on invested equity from user charges should become the norm. Over the past few years many Polish water and wastewater enterprises have already instituted major tariff increases for water and wastewater, and thereby raised their financial 1/ See PID dated September 1994 on the proposed Poland Municipal Development Project.
 - 4 - capacity close to full cost recovery levels. The city of Bielsko-Biala and others are setting impressive examples. Many Polish cities have the potential to reach full cost recovery rates through gradual and sustained increases without surpassing people's willingness and capacity to pay. 1.13 Improve investment planning, evaluation and selection. Investment planning and implementation in the past has been dominated by technical imperatives, often without sufficient concern for cost-effectiveness and economic considerations. Better investment selection and evaluation policies and processes must be introduced to ensure that the resources available are spent in the most cost-effective manner. Making better use of existing systems, setting priorities among investment choices, least-cost staging and life cycle costing and affordability considerations must become the guiding principles in selecting investments. Before contemplating investments in new capacity, utilities may derive savings by considering instead investments in such areas as the reduction of system leakage and water consumption combined with operational improvement programs aimed at reducing energy and other input costs. The present practice of looking at single component investments such as wastewater treatment plants separate from of a utility's other investment needs and overall financial considerations should be replaced with an approach that takes a more comprehensive and longer term view of a utility's development objectives, investment needs and financial capacity. Master plans and feasibility studies which combine technical, financial, institutional and economic considerations should become the basis for defining least-cost and affordable multi-year investment plans. 1.14 Introduce more cost-effective water management policies. Present effluent quality standards from municipal wastewater treatment plants are unnecessarily strict and, in many cases, exceed EU standards. Polish standards for wastewater treatment require biological treatment today and plan to introduce nutrient removal by the year 2000. For most Polish utilities, providing simple biological treatment to all wastewater is technically and financially a difficult task. Adding nutrient removal by the year 2000 is unaffordable for most utilities, as tariffs would have to increase to levels which utility customers in all likelihood would be unable to pay. The costs associated with advanced treatment far exceed the benefits from improved river water quality, especially when considering the opportunity cost of other higher priority investments-improving the quality of water supply services, for example-that may have to be curtailed. 1.15 A more rational solution to raising water quality and effluent standards would be to adopt EU or similar standards and allow water and wastewater utilities to comply in a phased manner with affordability and economic return as decision variables. This principle of phasing and setting clear priorities would be in agreement with the recommendation of European governments taken at their meeting in Luceme, Switzerland in 1993. Another consideration for optimizing the use of scarce resources would be to base resource allocation decisions on a river basin view that identifies priority investment opportunities to optimize resource use in terms of ambient water quality improvements. This should be reflected in the resource allocation policies of national, regional and municipal environmental funds which by providing significant amounts of concessional funds (over US$500 million in 1993 for all environmental investments) are an important driving force for investments in wastewater treatnient. 1.16 In the original design of the country's Water Law, first proposed in 1992, but not yet passed, regional water resources authorities modeled after the French Agence du Basin arrangement, were to assume an important role in allocating resources in accordance with priority. Recent political developments appear to have stalled this initiative, as control over the allocation of resources has been increasingly devolved to the country's 48 regional administrations (Voivodships) and municipalities. The dilution of resource allocation authority may lead to investment decisions with insufficient consideration
 of river basin strategy and priority. While this remains an unresolved issue, it does not affect any investment decisions for the proposed project. 1.17 Strengthen utility business support. In the past, goods and services required by water and wastewater utilities have been provided by state-owned engineering and design offices, equipment manufacturers and civil works contractors. Not directly accountable to utilities, the performance of these enterprises often was deficient in terms of product quality offered. To assist in the development of an efficient utility support industry capable of providing quality services and goods at a competitive price, many of these entities are in the process of privatization. This process can be sped up if water and wastewater utilities procure goods and services on the basis of competition, require internationally acceptable technical and performance specifications and conclude contracts that provide effective remedies for poor performance. Bank's Sector Assistance Strategy .18 Assistance to Poland's municipal water and wastewater sector is part of the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy. The proposed program for Bank involvement in the sector aims at supporting reforms outlined above. It proposes four different specific activities planned for the next three years: direct lending operations with the municipal water and wastewater utilities in Bielsko- Biala, Wroclaw, Krakow and Bydgoszcz. This first batch of projects is aimed at assisting local governments and water and wastewater enterprises in these cities to introduce many of the reforms outlined above and to provide benchmark examples for the sector in Poland. a direct lending operation for water and wastewater in Warsaw. Consultants financed under a US$1.5 million grant from EU (PHARE) have been engaged to prepare the project and Board presentation in FY98 is possible. A key element of project preparation is defining the Warsaw water and wastewater utility's future institutional status, with private sector participation in the management of the company being an option considered. Anticipating the large investment needs for Warsaw, cofinancing by private investors and use of the Bank's guarantee instrument would be pursued. smaller scale municipal water and wastewater projects included under the Municipal Development Project which is under preparation; wastewater investments for the project is under way. operations in support of innovative private sector participation; contacts are being established with several interested municipal govermnents. 1.19 These projects are designed to support, on the sector level, many of the elements of the Bank's Country Assistance Strategy: decentralization, public sector strengthening, fiscal responsibility, environmental protection and private sector participation. The projects are expected to have an important demonstration effect for the future development of the water and wastewater utilities in Poland and in other countries of Central and Eastern Europe.

INTRODUCTION 2.1 The proposed project would provide support for the water and wastewater enterprise in Bielsko-Biala (AQUA), a city of about 190,000 people in the south of the country. It is the first such project proposed under the Bank's sector assistance strategy. The project addresses AQUA's key development and investment needs: rehabilitating and upgrading the quality and efficiency of water and wastewater services, expanding wastewater treatment and improving management and operational efficiency. AQUA is a joint stock company, majority owned by the municipal government. A major goal of the project is to define more clearly the relationship between AQUA and the municipal government in order to enhance the autonomy of utility management. The company has adjusted tariffs significantly over the past four years and thereby has acquired the financial capacity to support major investments. The attached Project Information and Implementation Document (PIID) provides in Annex A a detailed description of Bielsko-Biala's present water and wastewater services, investment needs, and an institutional and financial analysis. 2.2 The project has been prepared by the prospective borrower with the assistance of international consultants financed by a bilateral grant. It was identified in late 1992 with feasibility studies initiated in late 1993 and completed in September 1994. The project was preappraised in September/October 1994 and appraised in March/April 1995. B. IMLEMENTATION SCHEDULE 3.1 The project would be implemented during the seven year span 1996-2002. As the Bank is just beginning to finance water and wastewater projects in the Region, no comparators exist to judge implementation periods. Although the proposed seven year implementation period is below the Bankwide average of eight years for water and wastewater projects, the accelerated schedule is considered feasible given the technical competence, commitment and financial soundness of the Borrower. B. IMPLEMENTATION MANAGEMENT 3.2 Project Implementation Manager/Unit. AQUA has appointed a full-time Project Implementation Manager (PIM) with overall responsibility for all aspects of project implementation and reporting directly to the General Manager. The PIM would lead a Project Implementation Unit (PIU) made up of individuals (engineers, accountants, support staff) drawn from the existing company structure. The PIU would be assisted by expert consultants to carry out final designs and bidding documents and supervise construction. One of the project objectives is the reorganization of the utility's institutional structure. Placement of the PIU in AQUA's future organizational structure would be considered carefully to ensure the effectiveness of this office, but also to integrate project management into the company's routine operation and command stream. AQUA agreed that the PIU headed by a full time qualified Project Implementation Manager (PIM) satisfactory to the Bank would be maintained throughout the project. 3.3 Flnal Design, Procurement and Supervision of Construction.  ANNEX E POLISH NATIONAL FUND FOR ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AND WATER MANAGEMENT Background and Objectives 1. The National Fund for Environmental Protection and Water Management (NFEP) is an independent state institution with the mission of financing environmental protection projects. The National Fund collects money from charges for the economic use of the environment as well as penalties for non- compliance with environmental protection regulations. 2. The National Fund was established through an amalgamation of two previously separate institutions-the Environmental Protection Fund and the Water Management Fund and commenced activities July 1989. The National Fund was later accompanied by the establishment of local and provincial funds for environmental protection and water management. These local and provincial funds, like the National Fund, receive revenues from various pollution charges and natural resource use fees. In general, 10 percent of the charges go to the local funds, with 60 percent of the remaining money to the provincial funds and 30 percent to the National Fund. The environmental funds all collect and disburse money for projects involving environmental protection. 3. Poland's environmental protection related expenditures rose from US$437 million in 1990 to US$889 million in 1993. Soft loans are the dominant form of financing extended by the National Fund and may be used to cover 50 percent of a project's cost. Award of a loan is conditional upon presentation of full financial coverage (inclusive of financing from NFEP) of the investment project. The National Fund also requires submission of an economic analysis of the project based on its business plan and financial projections. For projects where the amount requested for financing by the National Fund exceeds about US$225,000, project suppliers and contractors must be selected through competitive tendering. 7. Interest subsidies against loans originated by the Environmental Protection Bank are provided on the same terms as the soft loans offered by the National Fund-equivalent to the difference between the conmercial interest rate applied by the Environmental Protection Bank and the preferential rate applied by the National Fund. 8. Loan forgiveness is provided to investors who fulfill their contractual commitments vis a vis the National Fund and meet particular criteria. Not more that 50 percent of loan principal may be written off in this manner. Loan forgiveness is awarded to borrowers who meet National Fund requirements in terms of environmental benefits and loan repayment. Forgiveness decisions are issued with a clause requiring the beneficiary to apply the funds thus saved towards fuirther environmental protection.

doc.repnme: Poland - Bielsko-Biala Water and Wastewater Project
doc.abstracts: The overall objective of the Bielsko-Biala Water and Wastewater Project is to strengthen the management and operations of AQUA, a municipal company of Bielsko-Biala, upgrade water supply and wastewater collection services to improve the living standard and protect the health of the people of Bielsko-Biala and expand wastewater treatment to contribute to the clean up of the region's water resources. Specific objectives are to: 1) improve the safety, reliability and quality of water supply services by upgrading the functioning of water treatment plants and the water transmission and distribution network; 2) improve the efficiency of water production, transmission and distribution systems; 3) improve the safety, reliability and efficiency of the sewer system (pipe networks and pumping stations); 4) reduce pollution of local surface water; 5) reduce pollutant emissions into the Biala River; and 6) assist AQUA to improve its management and operations and strengthen its financial capacity and commercial orientation. The project will consist of the following components: 1) water supply including the expansion and improvement of the service to Zlote Lany area, the upgrading of the existing Wapienica, Szczyrk and Sola water treatment plants and rehabilitation and improvement of transmission-pumping-storage-distribution system; 2) wastewater which comprises the expansion of Wapienica and industrial wastewater collectors, the expansion of Komorowice capacity,the completion of Wapienica wastewater treatment plants and rehabilitation and improvement of the efficiency of the sewer system; 3) technical assistance and training; and 4) engineering design and construction supervision.
